communications.subject: Michigan Freedom of Information Act Request: Beverage Agreements (Oakland University)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Michigan Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Agreements related to the beverage pouring rights, distribution, or sales on campus or in athletics venues or facilities. Including any related exclusive marketing agreements for beverage brands in those areas.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Kelly North

communications.subject: Washington Public Records Act Request: Brady List (January 2025) (Clallam County Prosecuting Attorney)
communications.communication:

Pursuant to the Washington Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

All current "Brady lists" and "Giglio lists" (per Brady v. Maryland/Giglio v. United States) maintained by your office.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

communications.subject: [Document Released to Requester] Clallam County WA public records request #25-23
communications.communication:
Clallam County WA ************************************************************************ A document has been released for record request #25-23 along with the following message: Clallam County writes to acknowledge receipt of the public records request you submitted. Please accept this correspondence as our timely response to your request(s) as required under RCW 42.56.520. REQUEST: Pursuant to the Washington Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records: All current "Brady lists" and "Giglio lists" (per Brady v. Maryland/Giglio v. United States) maintained by your office. The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes. In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not. Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires. RESPONSE: Following a reasonable search, Clallam County has completed the assembly and duplication of all identifiable public records that respond to your request. At this time, we believe that we have responded to your request in full by making the records available to you in the Records Center. This request is now closed. As such, we do not intend to further address this request and the PRA's one-year statute of limitations to seek judicial review has started to run. If you believe that there are other records in existence that should have been released to you in response to this request, please notify the Public Records Office as soon as possible. Pursuant Clallam County Policy 321.17, fees for records requests shall be waived when the total fee for the request is under ten dollars. Since the total fee for this request is under ten dollars, no payment is due at this time. Pursuant to the Clallam County Administrative Policies and Procedures, any person who objects to the partial denial or redaction of a request for a Public Record may petition the Public Records Officer for a review of that decision. The petition must be in writing and include the petitioner’s name and contact information. The petition must be filed within 10 days of the denial. If you have difficulty downloading your records, click HERE for assistance. Please contact the Public Records Office if you have any questions or if you have difficultly accessing the electronic records. You can reach our office by responding to this message or by calling the phone number below. Sincerely, Jennifer Lindquist Deputy Public Records Officer Public Records, Information Technology Desk 360-417-2234 * .Brady List Excel Sheet.xlsx Document links are valid for one month. After February 7, you will need to sign in to view the document(s). ************************************************************************ Questions about your request? Reply to this email or sign in to contact staff at Clallam County WA.
Technical support: See our help page

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: Task-Based Work
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Any records, including administrative emails, memos, reports, and presentations, concerning the implementation of "task-based" work for eligibility workers (between 1/1/2021 and 11/13/2024).

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Josh Seim

communications.subject: RE: California Public Records Act Request: Task-Based Work
communications.communication:
Hello,

Thank you for the update. I understand my initial request was considered too broad and burdensome. I apologize. Please consider the modified request below:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

All internal memos/callouts regarding the implementation of "task-based" work sent to eligibility supervisors and eligibility workers from DPSS "line operations" (between 1/1/2021 and 12/31/2021). For reference, I am interested in how administrators communicated the shift from case-based work to task-based work to district office staff in 2021 (when most eligibility units shifted to a task-based system). 

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Josh Seim

communications.subject: Maryland Public Information Act Request: MPIA Request for IAD Records
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Maryland Public Information Act, I am hereby requesting access to the records listed below and held by the Baltimore Police Department:

- Copies of any and all internal affairs complaints, including internal, citizen, or other agency complaints of the following officers:

1. Raymond Hunter
2. Richard Moore
3. Robert Ross
4. Ryan O'Connor
5. Ryan Reass 
6. Sandra D Forsythe 
7. Sean Dallessandro
8. Sean Jones
9. Seth Roussey
10. Sharon Diggs
11. Shawn M Reichenberg
12. Steven Fraser
13. Thomas Jackson
14. Thomas Wolf
15. Tierra Morales
16. Trevor Hinton
17. Troy Taylor
18. Valencia Vaughn
19. Vernon Fuller

- Complete investigative files for each complaint, including but not limited to reports of recorded statements, video surveillance or body camera footage, investigative files, witness interviews, and photographs.
- The investigative findings of each complaint.
- Any correspondence from the Civilian Review Board, Police Advisory Commission or other civilian police oversight board.
- The final disposition of each case, if any.

****As with previous requests of this nature,  we will accept disciplinary history summaries for all of the officers listed for the time being.****

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request.  Alternatively, please consider waiving any fees, pursuant to § 4-206(e)(2)(ii) of the General Provisions Article, as this request is on behalf of individuals served by the Maryland Office of the Public Defender, a state government agency, which solely serves indigent citizens of Maryland.  As a result, my request for the above-listed public records is in the public interest.  I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Deborah Levi
Director of Special Litigation
Maryland Office of the Public Defender
(443) 272-1068

communications.subject: Acknowledgement Letter for MPIA 24-1808
communications.communication:
Dear Deborah Levi,

This is an acknowledgement of your request below, for public information, submitted to the Document Compliance Unit ("DCU") of the Baltimore Police Department ("BPD").  Your request is governed by the Maryland Public Information Act ("PIA"), Maryland Code, General Provisions Article ("GP"), Sections 4-101 et seq.  DCU will process your request promptly.  However, our response may take longer than ten (10) working days, the reasons for which may include the scope of your request, the type and volume of potentially responsive records, and the nature of the search, review, and preparation that is required.  In any event, DCU will respond to your request within thirty (30) days. GP § 4-203.

DCU will contact you with the availability of records and the possible costs associated with this request, as soon as the information is made available by the Custodian of Records.  Likewise, if DCU and/or the Custodian of Records need you to clarify your request, DCU will contact you promptly.
The DCU staff receive overwhelming number of requests a month and we are working diligently to respond to each and every request as quickly as possible. We appreciate your patience; response to document requests may take longer than normal.

Please refer to tracking # MPIA 24-1808  in any subsequent correspondence pertaining to this matter.  All follow up correspondence should be made in writing and submitted to the DCU's e-mail: DCU@baltimorepolice.org<mailto:DCU@baltimorepolice.org>.

DCU

BPD

communications.communication:
Good afternoon Deborah Levi,

On June 5, 2024, you submitted a request for public records to the Document Compliance Unit ("DCU") of the Baltimore Police Department ("BPD"), for -Copies of any and all internal affairs complaints, including internal, citizen, or other agency complaints for (19) officers.

1. Raymond Hunter
2. Richard Moore
3. Robert Ross
4. Ryan O'Connor
5. Ryan Reass
6. Sandra D Forsythe
7. Sean Dallessandro
8. Sean Jones
9. Seth Roussey
10. Sharon Diggs
11. Shawn M Reichenberg
12. Steven Fraser
13. Thomas Jackson
14. Thomas Wolf
15. Tierra Morales
16. Trevor Hinton
17. Troy Taylor
18. Valencia Vaughn
19. Vernon Fuller

- Complete investigative files for each complaint, including but not limited to reports of recorded statements, video surveillance or body camera footage, investigative files, witness interviews, and photographs.
- The investigative findings of each complaint. - Any correspondence from the Civilian Review Board, Police Advisory Commission or other civilian police oversight board. - The final disposition of each case, if any.

The Maryland Public Information Act ("PIA"), Annotated Code of Maryland, General Provisions Article, § 4-101, et seq. governs your request. The responsive record(s) are maintained by the Document Compliance Unit, DCU of BPD.

               DCU's Response:

               Attached are the remaining PIB Discipline Reports for the requested officers. No records were found for Thomas Wolf or Tierra Morales.

Nothing in this response is intended to indicate that any records sought from BPD exist or to waive any privileges held by BPD. You have a right under the Public Information Act for the Public Access Ombudsman to mediate any disputes arising out of a MPIA request or a judicial review pursuant to General Provisions Article §§ 4-1B-04, 4-362. communications.subject: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request: Event Records (Waltham Police Department)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Massachusetts Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

1. Records pertaining to detentions and arrests on or immediately surrounding Brandeis University's campus at 415 South Street in Waltham, MA., between September and December in the year 2023.
This should include: incident reports, case reports, supplemental reports, body-worn camera footage (if applicable), dash-cam footage (if applicable), 911 call recordings and transcripts, radio communications or dispatch logs, emails or text messages between officers, supervisors, and other officials about the incident, internal memos, briefings, or reports regarding the event, CAD (Computer-Aided Dispatch) logs, arrest reports (if applicable), and booking records.

Note for Mass. PD (Waltham PD ignore this): Brandeis Campus PD is implicated in this request as a subsidiary of Massachusetts State Police. It is subject to public records requests. See: Chapter 22C, Section 63 of the Massachusetts General laws, which allows college and university police officers to be appointed as Special State Police Officers under the authority of the Colonel of the Massachusetts State Police.

I also request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as we believe this request is in the public interest, as suggested but not stipulated by the recommendations of the Massachusetts Supervisor of Public Records. The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, and is not made for commercial usage.

I expect the request to be filled in an accessible format, including for screen readers, which provide text-to-speech for persons unable to read print. Files that are not accessible to screen readers include, for example, .pdf image files as well as physical documents.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

UT

communications.subject: Nevada Public Records Act Request: Police data collection (2017-2022)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Nevada Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

1. the total number of use of force incidents from 2020-2023, separated by year. Please include, as part of this a breakdown, how many use of force incidents were related to law enforcement operations 
2. the total number of use of force incidents, separated by year and type of force, from 2020-2023 (for example, information that specifies the number of taser incidents in 2023, baton incidents in 2023, etc.)
3. the total number of civilian complaints against law enforcement that were reported and the total number sustained from 2020-2023, separated by year.  
4. the total number of civilian complaints alleging law enforcement use of excessive force that were reported and the total number sustained from 2020-2023, separated by year. 
5. the total number of civilian complaints alleging biased policing or racial profiling that were reported and the total number sustained from 2020-2023, separated by year.  
6. the total number of civilian complaints alleging criminal conduct that were reported and the total number sustained from 2020-2023, separated by year. 
7. the total number of officer-involved shootings from 2020-2023, both fatal and non-fatal, separated by year.
8. the total number of people who the sheriff’s department used force against, broken down by race/ethnicity
9. Complaints filed by one officer towards another officer

When available, please provide the data in separate CSV files by year.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Alessandro Guzman

communications.subject: Public Records Request #2025010604
communications.communication:

title: Subject: Comprehensive FOIA Request for Connecticut Medicaid Acquired Brain Injury Waiver Program Records (Department of Consumer Protection)

communications.subject: Connecticut Freedom of Information Act Request: Subject: Comprehensive FOIA Request for Connecticut Medicaid Acquired Brain Injury Waiver Program Records (Department of Consumer Protection)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Connecticut Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Freedom of Information Officers
Subject: Comprehensive FOIA Request for Connecticut Medicaid Acquired Brain Injury Waiver Program Records

Dear Freedom of Information Officers,

I am writing to formally request access to all records under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) (5 U.S.C. § 552) and relevant Connecticut state laws, specifically related to the Connecticut Medicaid Acquired Brain Injury (ABI) Waiver Program. This information is critical to my participation in the oversight and administration of this program.

In accordance with Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 (29 U.S.C. § 794) and the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) (42 U.S.C. § 12101 et seq.), I am requesting accommodations due to my condition. I respectfully request that all records be provided electronically via email, as opposed to portals or complex delivery methods, to ensure full and equal access to the information.

Scope of Request:
Legislative Records:

All bills, amendments, resolutions, legislative proposals, and legislative history related to the Connecticut Medicaid ABI Waiver Program.
Voting records of all state and federal legislators on any legislation affecting the Medicaid ABI Waiver Program.
Minutes, transcripts, and audio/video recordings of meetings, hearings, or discussions where the Medicaid ABI Waiver Program was a topic.
Public Records:

Comprehensive reports, studies, assessments, and evaluations on the Connecticut Medicaid ABI Waiver Program.
Budget allocations, financial statements, expenditure reports, and audit results related to the program, pursuant to Connecticut Budget Transparency Laws (C.G.S. § 4-66 and related sections).
All contracts, agreements, memoranda of understanding, and intergovernmental agreements involving the administration or management of the Medicaid ABI Waiver Program.
Correspondence:

All emails, letters, and other forms of communication, including internal and external, regarding the Medicaid ABI Waiver Program.
Internal memoranda, briefing documents, policy directives, and decision-making correspondence related to the oversight and implementation of the program.
Personnel Records:

Non-confidential employment records, including job descriptions, resumes, and performance evaluations, of individuals involved in the administration and oversight of the Medicaid ABI Waiver Program. This request is consistent with the Privacy Act of 1974 (5 U.S.C. § 552a), which protects confidential personal data.
Organizational charts detailing the structure and personnel responsible for managing the Medicaid ABI Waiver Program within relevant state and federal agencies.
Program Information:

All guidelines, protocols, procedural documents, and compliance reviews governing the operation of the Medicaid ABI Waiver Program, as mandated by Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) Regulations (42 CFR § 440.180) for home and community-based services waiver programs.
Implementation plans, performance metrics, outcome reports, and evaluation summaries regarding the effectiveness of the program.
Comprehensive data sets related to enrollment, utilization, demographic information, and outcomes of beneficiaries participating in the Medicaid ABI Waiver Program.
Special Requests:
Expedited Processing: Pursuant to Executive Order 13392, which mandates the improvement of agency disclosure processes, and the Freedom of Information Act (5 U.S.C. § 552), I request expedited processing of this FOIA request due to the public interest and personal impact of the information.

Electronic Records: In compliance with my rights under Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act and the ADA, I request that all records be provided in electronic format and sent directly to my email address. This will ensure that I can access the information without unnecessary barriers or delays.

Fee Waiver Request:
I request a waiver of all fees associated with this FOIA request under 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(A)(iii). This request is made in the public interest and not for commercial use. The disclosure of the requested information will significantly contribute to public understanding of government operations, particularly concerning the Connecticut Medicaid ABI Waiver Program, which impacts a vulnerable population. Additionally, due to my condition, as covered by Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act, a fee waiver will ensure equitable access to this important information.

Relevant Laws:
This FOIA request, and the accommodations I am requesting, are governed by the following laws and regulations:

Freedom of Information Act (5 U.S.C. § 552) – Governing the right to request access to federal records.
Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) (42 U.S.C. § 12101 et seq.) – Ensuring equal access for individuals with disabilities, including in communication.
Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 (29 U.S.C. § 794) – Prohibiting discrimination based on disability in programs receiving federal funding.
Privacy Act of 1974 (5 U.S.C. § 552a) – Protecting personal privacy in records maintained by federal agencies.
Medicaid Statute (Title XIX of the Social Security Act) (42 U.S.C. § 1396 et seq.) – Governing Medicaid programs, including waivers like the ABI Waiver.
Connecticut Freedom of Information Act (C.G.S. §§ 1-200 to 1-242) – Governing the right to request access to state records.
Connecticut Budget Transparency Laws (C.G.S. § 4-66) – Requiring public disclosure of state budget allocations and financial reports.
CMS Regulations (42 CFR § 440.180) – Governing the administration of home and community-based services waiver programs, including the ABI Waiver.
Executive Order 13392 ("Improving Agency Disclosure of Information") – Mandating federal agencies to improve FOIA processing.
Non-Waiver of Rights:
This request does not waive any rights I may have under FOIA, the ADA, the Rehabilitation Act, or any other applicable law, and I reserve all rights regarding this matter.

Thank you for your prompt attention to this request and for accommodating my needs.

Sincerely,
David Medeiros
ABI Resources

Departments of Submission:
State of Connecticut Agencies:
Connecticut Department of Social Services (DSS)
Email: foia.dss@ct.gov
Department: Department of Social Services

Connecticut Office of the Attorney General
Email: attorney.general@ct.gov
Department: Office of the Attorney General

Connecticut General Assembly (CGA)
Email: foia@cga.ct.gov
Department: Connecticut General Assembly

Connecticut Office of Policy and Management (OPM)
Email: opm.foia@ct.gov
Department: Office of Policy and Management

Connecticut Department of Public Health (DPH)
Email: dph.foi@ct.gov
Department: Department of Public Health

Federal Agencies:
U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS)
Email: HHS_FOIA@hhs.gov
Department: U.S. Department of Health and Human Services

Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS)
Email: FOIA_Request@cms.hhs.gov
Department: Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services

U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ)
Email: foia.requests@usdoj.gov
Department: U.S. Department of Justice

U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD)
Email: foiarequests@hud.gov
Department: U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development

U.S. Department of Labor (DOL)
Email: foiarequests@dol.gov
Department: U.S. Department of Labor

Federal Trade Commission (FTC)
Email: FOIA@ftc.gov
Department: Federal Trade Commission

I also request that, if possible and pursuant to Conn. Gen. Stat. § 1-212(d), fees be waived as I believe this request is in the public interest and not made for commercial gain. The requested documents will be made available to the public at MuckRock.com.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 4 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

DAVID MEDEIROS

communications.subject: RE: Connecticut Freedom of Information Act Request #R000354-102024
communications.communication:
Subject: Appeal of FOIA Request Determination – Connecticut Medicaid ABI Waiver Program Records
Reference: FOIA Request # R000354-102024

To the FOIA Appeals Officer,

I am submitting this appeal concerning my FOIA request (Reference # R000354-102024) submitted to the Connecticut Department of Consumer Protection (DCP) for records related to the Connecticut Medicaid Acquired Brain Injury (ABI) Waiver Program. The recent response indicated that DCP does not maintain records for the ABI Waiver Program, and I was directed to the Connecticut Department of Social Services (DSS) for further inquiries. However, I am seeking additional clarification and guidance on potential relevant records within DCP.

Basis for Appeal
This appeal is intended to confirm the scope of DCP’s search and determine if there may be additional records indirectly related to the ABI Waiver Program, especially regarding consumer protection policies, fraud prevention, or provider standards oversight.

Clarification on Scope of Records Reviewed:
While DCP has indicated that the ABI Waiver Program is not under its direct jurisdiction, I respectfully request confirmation as to whether any records linked to consumer protection standards, fraud monitoring, or provider services oversight for Medicaid programs were included in this search. Given the program’s public interest implications, these types of records, if available, would be essential for transparency.

Interagency Communications:
If DCP has been involved in any interagency consultations or communications with DSS, the Office of Policy and Management (OPM), or other state entities concerning Medicaid provider standards or consumer protection relevant to the ABI Waiver Program, I respectfully request access to those records. Should these documents reside in another agency, I would appreciate guidance on the correct contacts for a redirected FOIA request.

Fee Waiver Confirmation:
As this request is intended to benefit public understanding of health and consumer service oversight, I reiterate my request for a fee waiver under Conn. Gen. Stat. § 1-212(d).

Relief Requested
I respectfully request that DCP conduct a supplementary review for any responsive records indirectly related to the ABI Waiver Program or confirm that no such records exist within DCP. If no relevant records are held, any guidance on alternative state agencies or departments that may maintain these records would be greatly appreciated.

Basic Accommodation Requests
To support my full participation in this process, I request the following basic accommodations:

Email-Only Communication: Please correspond exclusively via email at AabiWR@live.com.
Response in Email Body: Include the substantive response directly in the email body, ensuring easy access.
Identification of FOIA Representatives: Please include names, titles, and contact details of representatives handling my request.
Avoid Portals or External Links: Ensure all necessary information is accessible directly within the email.
Thank you for your attention to this appeal. If further information is required to clarify or assist with locating these records, please contact me at AabiWR@live.com.

Sincerely,

David Medeiros
Founder & Owner, ABI Resources
39 Kings HWY STE C
Gales Ferry, Connecticut, 06335
AabiWR@live.com

Subject: Appeal of FOIA Request Determination – Connecticut Medicaid ABI Waiver Program Records
Reference: FOIA Request #R000354-102024

CC:
DCP Legal Department
ADA Compliance Officer

Introduction
This appeal challenges the Connecticut Department of Consumer Protection’s (DCP) determination, dated October 23, 2024, stating that no responsive records exist concerning my FOIA request for records related to the Connecticut Medicaid Acquired Brain Injury (ABI) Waiver Program. This response lacks sufficient scope, clarity, and consideration of interagency communications, consumer protection standards, and broader ethical or regulatory oversight of Medicaid-funded services.

Under the Constitution of the United States, Connecticut Freedom of Information Act (C.G.S. §§ 1-200 to 1-242), FOIA (5 U.S.C. § 552), and related laws, I respectfully request a supplemental review of my request, adherence to statutory transparency obligations, and proper application of accessibility accommodations.

Basis for Appeal
1. Constitutional Rights to Transparency and Equal Treatment
First Amendment: The right to access government-held information ensures transparency, a cornerstone of democratic governance. Denial or incomplete fulfillment of FOIA requests obstructs the public's ability to oversee government operations involving public funds and vulnerable populations.
Fourteenth Amendment – Equal Protection and Due Process: The procedural failure to conduct a comprehensive search and provide clear guidance violates due process. Equal access to oversight of Medicaid programs for disabled individuals is a constitutional mandate.
Supremacy Clause (Article VI, U.S. Constitution): Federal laws, such as the ADA and Rehabilitation Act, preempt conflicting state practices and require accessibility in government communications and record-keeping.
2. Statutory and Regulatory Violations
A. Connecticut FOIA (C.G.S. §§ 1-200 to 1-242):
Requires prompt access to public records held by state agencies. DCP’s determination failed to confirm whether all records within its jurisdiction—including interagency communications—were thoroughly reviewed.
Under C.G.S. § 1-212(d), I request a fee waiver for this public interest request, as it seeks to advance understanding of Medicaid-funded services.
B. Federal FOIA (5 U.S.C. § 552):
Requires a comprehensive search of all reasonably identifiable records, including interagency communications (5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(3)(C)).
Mandates detailed explanations for determinations, including the scope of the search, offices queried, and any statutory exemptions applied (5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6)(C)(i)).
C. Americans with Disabilities Act (42 U.S.C. § 12101 et seq.):
Requires state agencies to provide effective communication and equal access to government services, including accommodations for individuals with disabilities.
Failure to provide accommodations or clarify the scope of determinations violates federal accessibility laws.
D. Rehabilitation Act (29 U.S.C. § 794):
Prohibits discrimination in programs receiving federal funding, mandating accommodations in FOIA responses, including simplified summaries and accessible formats.
E. Medicaid Statute (42 U.S.C. § 1396 et seq.):
Governs Medicaid programs, including the ABI Waiver, requiring transparency in funding, provider oversight, and program operations.
F. Executive Order 13392 ("Improving Agency Disclosure of Information"):
Mandates improved FOIA processing to ensure timely, transparent, and equitable access to records.
3. Failure to Conduct a Comprehensive Search
Consumer Protection Oversight: While DCP states the ABI Waiver Program is not under its direct jurisdiction, I request confirmation of whether:
DCP holds records on consumer protection standards for Medicaid providers under the ABI Waiver Program.
Any fraud prevention, consumer complaints, or provider standards oversight involving ABI Waiver providers were included in the search.
Interagency Communications: If DCP participated in consultations with DSS, the Office of Policy and Management (OPM), or other agencies regarding the ABI Waiver Program, those records must be disclosed.
Relief Requested
To resolve this matter, I respectfully request:

1. Expanded Record Search
Conduct a supplementary search across all DCP divisions for:
Records on consumer protection, provider standards, fraud investigations, and interagency consultations related to Medicaid programs.
Communications with DSS, OPM, or CMS concerning ABI Waiver Program oversight or provider regulations.
2. Clarification of Initial Determination
Provide a detailed explanation of the initial search process, including:
Offices and databases queried.
Search terms used.
Timeframes covered.
3. Referrals to Other Agencies
If records are confirmed to exist outside DCP, provide a referral under C.G.S. § 1-212(b) to DSS or other relevant agencies.
4. Adherence to ADA and Rehabilitation Act Accommodations
Non-Negotiable ADA Accommodations:
MuckRock Platform, Only Communication:

All responses via MuckRock; phone calls, physical mail, passwords, or portal responses are prohibited.
Direct Text in Body:

Response text embedded in the email body for accessibility.
PDF Attachments for Documents:

Clearly labeled and properly formatted PDFs that are screen-reader compatible.
Simplified Summaries for Complex Records:

Includes summaries for ease of comprehension, ensuring all records are accessible and understandable.
Identification of Responsible Personnel:

Names, titles, and contact information of all responsible individuals (FOIA officers and supervisory personnel) must be included.
Detailed Justifications for Redactions and Denials:

Must include statutory explanations for any redactions or denials, in compliance with 5 U.S.C. § 552(b).
Expedited Processing:

Requests must be processed expeditiously as mandated under 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6)(E) and Executive Order 13392.
5. Expedited Processing
Confirm expedited processing under C.G.S. § 1-212(d) and 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6)(E), given the public interest and urgency related to Medicaid transparency.
6. Fee Waiver Confirmation
Approve a fee waiver under C.G.S. § 1-212(d) and 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(A)(iii), as this request advances public understanding of government operations without commercial use.
7. Estimated Completion Date
Provide an estimated completion date under 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(7)(B)(ii) for processing this appeal.
Conclusion
This appeal reinforces constitutional and statutory rights to government transparency, public accountability, and equitable access for individuals with disabilities. I trust that DCP will act promptly and comprehensively to address these concerns. Please provide a substantive response within the statutory timeframe.

Thank you for your attention to this matter.

Sincerely,
David Medeiros
Founder & Owner, ABI Resources
39 Kings HWY STE C
Gales Ferry, Connecticut, 06335
Email: AabiWR@live.com

Attachments:

Original FOIA Request (10/17/2024)
DCP Response Letter (10/23/2024)
Initial Appeal Submission (11/01/2024)

communications.subject: RE: Connecticut Freedom of Information Act Request #R000354-102024
communications.communication:
12.04.2024 Subject: Appeal Immediate Compliance Required with ADA Accommodations and FOIA Obligations

Dear FOIA Officer
I am writing to formally reiterate my request for specific ADA accommodations and compliance with FOIA obligations, which are essential for my full participation in this process. These accommodations were explicitly requested to address accessibility needs stemming from my traumatic brain injury and to ensure compliance with federal law. To date, your office has failed to meet these requirements, resulting in undue barriers and systemic non-compliance.

Accommodations Previously Requested
The following accommodations, explicitly outlined in prior communications, remain unfulfilled:

Exclusive Use of MuckRock Platform

Requested: All communications must be routed exclusively through the MuckRock platform. No external portals, password-protected links, or alternate communication methods are acceptable.
Non-Compliance: Communications have directed me to use external portals and password-protected links, violating ADA guidelines and my explicit requests.
Accessible Document Formatting

Requested: All documents must be provided as screen-reader compatible PDFs, properly labeled and indexed for ease of navigation and accessibility.
Non-Compliance: Provided documents have not adhered to accessibility standards, preventing effective access to critical information.
Simplified Summaries for Complex Records

Requested: Simplified summaries must accompany all complex or technical records to enhance comprehension and ensure equitable participation.
Non-Compliance: No summaries have been provided, creating unnecessary barriers to understanding the records.
Identification of Responsible Personnel

Requested: Each communication must include the name, title, and role of the individual responsible for processing or responding to my requests.
Non-Compliance: Correspondence has consistently lacked this information, hindering accountability and effective follow-up.

Immediate Action Required
To rectify these ongoing failures and ensure compliance with federal laws, I demand the following actions be taken without delay:

Transition All Communications to MuckRock

Immediately cease the use of external portals or non-compliant communication methods and ensure all responses are routed exclusively through the MuckRock platform.
Provide Accessible Documents

Reformat and resend all previously provided documents as screen-reader compatible PDFs, properly labeled and indexed to ensure accessibility.
Include Simplified Summaries

Provide simplified summaries for all complex or technical records, both previously shared and in future communications, to ensure accessibility and equitable participation.
Identify Responsible Personnel

Include the name, title, and role of the individual responsible for every communication moving forward to ensure transparency and accountability.
Legal Basis for Compliance
Your office is legally obligated to comply with these accommodations under the following statutes and principles:

Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA): Title II, 42 U.S.C. § 12132, and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act mandate reasonable accommodations and accessibility in communications for individuals with disabilities.
Freedom of Information Act (FOIA): 5 U.S.C. § 552 requires transparency, accessibility, and adherence to procedural fairness.
Constitutional Protections: The First, Fifth, and Fourteenth Amendments to the U.S. Constitution safeguard my rights to petition the government, due process, and equal protection under the law.
Executive Order 13392: Mandates improved agency disclosure of information to enhance transparency and accountability.

Deadline for Compliance
Your office must confirm compliance with these accommodations and provide the requested corrective actions within five (5) business days of this notice. Continued non-compliance will be documented as a violation of the ADA and FOIA and may result in escalation, including:

Formal Complaints: Filing with the U.S. Department of Justice and the Office for Civil Rights.
Judicial Remedies: Seeking injunctive relief and damages for ADA and FOIA violations.
Public Advocacy: Reporting systemic failures to oversight agencies, media, and advocacy organizations.
Conclusion
This communication serves as a final request for compliance. It is imperative that your office address these deficiencies promptly to restore transparency, accessibility, and adherence to federal law.

Thank you for your immediate attention to this matter. I look forward to your response and resolution by the stated deadline.

Sincerely,
David Medeiros
Founder, ABI Resources
DB.42.131.Inf.

CC
Federal Officials
Merrick B. Garland

Date: January 1, 2025
01/01/2025 




To:
FOIA Appeals Officer
Connecticut Department of Consumer Protection (DCP)
Legal Division
450 Columbus Blvd, Suite 901
Hartford, CT 06103

CC:
State and Federal Oversight Officials (full list provided in attached correspondence)

Subject: Comprehensive Escalated Appeal and Legal Complaint Under FOIA, ADA, Taxpayer Protections, and Constitutional Law
Reference: FOIA Request #R000354-102024

Introduction and Summary
This appeal challenges DCP’s determination, dated October 23, 2024, asserting no responsive records for my FOIA request regarding the Connecticut Medicaid Acquired Brain Injury (ABI) Waiver Program. The handling of this request reflects systemic non-compliance with FOIA, ADA, and federal taxpayer protection statutes, undermining transparency, accessibility, and constitutional rights.

This appeal and complaint demand immediate rectification of the deficiencies, a comprehensive supplemental search, full ADA compliance, and legal accountability for the mismanagement of federally funded Medicaid programs.

Key Legal Violations
Constitutional Rights

First Amendment: Denying access to public records infringes on my right to petition for redress of grievances.
Fifth and Fourteenth Amendments: Procedural delays and failure to provide accessible responses violate due process and equal protection.
Supremacy Clause: Federal ADA and Rehabilitation Act obligations preempt conflicting state practices.
FOIA and Connecticut FOIA

5 U.S.C. § 552 and C.G.S. §§ 1-200 et seq.: Failure to conduct a comprehensive search, clarify scope, or justify determinations violates FOIA.
Failure to Provide Justifications: DCP must cite specific statutory exemptions for withheld or non-responsive records, per NARA v. Favish.
Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA)

Title II, 42 U.S.C. § 12132: DCP’s failure to adhere to requested accommodations (e.g., accessible formatting, MuckRock-exclusive communication) constitutes discrimination.
28 C.F.R. § 35.160: Agencies must ensure effective communication with individuals with disabilities.
Rehabilitation Act

29 U.S.C. § 794: Federally funded programs must provide reasonable accommodations to ensure equitable access.
Whistleblower and Taxpayer Protections

5 U.S.C. § 2302(b)(8): Failure to address whistleblower claims related to Medicaid mismanagement jeopardizes accountability for taxpayer-funded programs.
Relief Sought
Comprehensive Supplemental Search:

Query all DCP divisions for records on consumer protection standards, fraud prevention, and interagency communications related to Medicaid-funded services, including ABI Waiver Program providers.
Search terms must include “ABI Waiver Program,” “Medicaid provider oversight,” and “fraud investigations.”
Clarification of Scope and Determination:

Provide a detailed explanation of search parameters (e.g., databases queried, timeframes covered) and identify statutory exemptions for withheld records.
Referral to Appropriate Agencies:

Forward the request to DSS or any other agency maintaining relevant records and provide written confirmation of the referral.
Compliance with ADA Accommodations:

ADA Accommodations Request
This request includes explicit ADA accommodations to address cognitive processing challenges resulting from my traumatic brain injury (TBI). These accommodations are legally required under Title II of the ADA (42 U.S.C. § 12132) and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act (29 U.S.C. § 794).

Requested ADA Accommodations
To ensure accessibility and compliance with ADA standards (42 U.S.C. § 12101 et seq.), I request the following accommodations for all communications and records:

Screen-Reader Compatible Formats

All documents must be provided in properly labeled PDFs or plain-text files.
Ensure the documents are screen-reader compatible and retain clear formatting.
Exclusive MuckRock Platform Communication

All communications must occur via the MuckRock platform.
Do not send external links, emails, portals, passwords, codes, or require phone calls for access.
Text Embedded in Email Bodies

Key information must be embedded directly in the email body to facilitate comprehension.
Simplified Summaries

Provide plain-language summaries for complex or legal documents to ensure clarity.
Identification of Responsible Officers

Include the full name, title, and contact information of all responsible officers handling this request.
Non-Negotiable Compliance
These accommodations are non-negotiable and are essential for ensuring equal access to information. Any failure to provide the requested accommodations may constitute a violation of the ADA and the Rehabilitation Act. Thank you for ensuring compliance and accessibility in addressing this request.

All responses must be routed through the MuckRock platform to ensure accessibility.
Accessible Document Formatting:

PDFs must be labeled, indexed, and screen-reader compatible, with logical organization.
Simplified Summaries:

Provide plain-language summaries for complex or technical records to ensure equitable access.
Identification of Responsible Personnel:

Include the name, title, and contact information of all individuals involved in processing this request.
Expedited Processing:

Prioritize this appeal under 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6)(E) and C.G.S. § 1-210(a), given the public interest in Medicaid transparency.
Consequences of Continued Non-Compliance
Formal Complaints:

Complaints will be filed with the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) Civil Rights Division, HHS OCR, and state oversight bodies.
Judicial Action:

Injunctive relief and damages will be pursued under FOIA, ADA, and constitutional law.
Public Advocacy:

Systemic failures will be reported to media outlets and taxpayer advocacy groups to ensure accountability.
Deadline for Compliance
This appeal requires a substantive response within five (5) business days. Failure to comply will result in immediate escalation to federal oversight authorities and legal remedies.

Conclusion
This complaint seeks to uphold constitutional, statutory, and ethical obligations for transparency, ADA compliance, and taxpayer protections. By addressing these violations promptly and comprehensively, DCP can restore public trust and demonstrate accountability in administering Medicaid-funded programs.

Attachments:

Original FOIA Request (10/17/2024)
DCP Response Letter (10/23/2024)
Initial Appeal Submission (11/01/2024)

Sincerely,
David Medeiros
Founder, ABI Resources

Sincerely,
David Medeiros
Founder, ABI Resources

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: PRA on pro-Palestine Encampment Protests
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

- Emails from UC President Michael Drake, UC Regents and UC chancellors referencing policing of pro-Palestine encampment protests from March 2024-October 2024. 
- Emails from UC President Michael Drake and UC Regents referencing his departure from the UC System from May 2024-August 2024
- Emails from UC Police Chiefs and Michael Drake referencing the 2021 Campus Policing Plan from March 2024-October 2024
- Emails from UC President Michael Drake and UC Regents referencing students arrested in pro-Palestine protests from April 2024-June 2024
- Emails from representatives of UC’s investors or representatives of any corporation to UC Regents or President Michael Drake referencing pro-Palestine protest encampments from April 2024-October 2024
- Emails between state officials and UC Regents and/or UC President Michael Drake that reference pro-Palestine encampment protests from April 2024-October 2024

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Atmika Iyer

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: Agency Roster (Fullerton Police Department)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Please provide records sufficient to show a current staff roster of all sworn employees with your agency.

Please include;
- first and last name of each employee with their corresponding;
- badge number
- employee identification number
- hire date
- rank or position
- assigned duty station/substation/precinct/location
- current annual salary

This request applies to ALL sworn Department employees, including those at substations.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Marcus Boyd

title: Skydio/Axon communications and materials (San Mateo Police Department)

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: Skydio/Axon communications and materials (San Mateo Police Department)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

In a recent city council meeting (https://sanmateo.primegov.com/Portal/Meeting?meetingTemplateId=8018) Amendment No. 3 to the master services and purchasing agreement with Axon Enterprise, Inc. was approved for use of a Skydio X10 drone and associated Skydio Remote Flight Deck Software.

Therefore, I hereby request the following records, from Jan 01, 2024 to the processing of this request:

1) Any digital communications (including but not limited to emails and text messages) as well as documents, (including but not limited to PDF, word processing, excel, and slide documents) that mention "Skydio", "X10", or "Remote Flight Deck". This includes communications from Skydio, Axon Enterprise, Inc., or any other external entities that may have been consulted. Please include all attachments.

2) All instructional materials, presentations and presentation materials (including recorded video and audio, and PowerPoint files), and other guidance on the features and use of Skydio drones. This can exclude notes taken during meetings, but should include A) any explanations (whether internally or externally generated) of how Skydio works, and B) any other document that has been used to help explain the use of Skydio, including internal documentation, public relations materials, and executive summaries.

3) A copy of any materials related to evaluation of the addition of Skydio equipment (such as possible effects on privacy impact assessments, use policies, standard operating procedures, or data retention policies) not covered by (1) (such as meeting notes not captured in email).

I also request that any records maintained in an electronic format be provided in that same format (such as a PDF, XLS, or PPT file), to avoid copying costs.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Ewen Cheslack-Postava

communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Iowa Open Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

Find the request for proposal, award notices, statement of work, and contract awarded to the University of Iowa by the Iowa Department of Health and Human Services for the Child Care Subsidy Management program.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Toni Thompson

communications.subject: RE: Iowa Open Records Law Request: Contract Awarded to University of Iowa for Child Care Subsidy Management
communications.communication:

I wanted to follow up on the following Iowa Open Records Law request, copied below, and originally submitted on Dec. 13, 2024. Please let me know when I can expect to receive a response.

Thanks for your help, and let me know if further clarification is needed.

communications.subject: Re: Iowa Open Records Law Request: Contract Awarded to University of Iowa for Child Care Subsidy Management
communications.communication:
Hello and thank you for your request.  The Iowa Department of Health and Human Services had not received this request until today, 12-20-2024 and we will be happy to process.

You may view the Department's open records policy at Open Records Policy<https://hhs.iowa.gov/initiatives/open-records>.

Iowa HHS attempts to determine if we have responsive records that can be released within 10 business days, but it may take longer based on the complexity of your request or workload and staffing issues.  I'll do my best to keep you updated if we will require additional time on this request.

Please let me know if you have any questions at this time.  Thank you for your request.



HHS Open Records

Division of Compliance

Iowa Department of Health and Human Services

321 E 12th St., Des Moines, IA 50319

Hhsopenrecords@hhs.iowa.gov

HHS.Iowa.gov<http://hhs.iowa.gov/>

HHS Open Records

Iowa Department of Health and Human Services

321 E 12th St., Des Moines, IA 50319

communications.communication:
Hello Toni,



Please find the attached letter and Memo of Understanding attached regarding your request.  Iowa HHS will consider this request closed at this time.  Thank you for your request.



Iowa HHS is working continuously to improve our processes.  Attached you will find a survey for you to provide feedback on your experience.  We appreciate your time in completing this survey, survey<https://ihhshr.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_1SJ9SYMKOedaKCW>.





HHS Open Records

Division of Compliance

Iowa Department of Health and Human Services

321 E 12th St., Des Moines, IA 50319

communications.subject: Georgia Open Records Act Request: Agency Roster (Chatham County Police Department)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Georgia Open Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Please provide records sufficient to show a current staff roster of all sworn employees with your agency.

Please include;
- first and last name of each employee with their corresponding;
- badge number
- employee identification number
- hire date
- rank or position
- assigned duty station/substation/precinct/location
- current salary

This request applies to ALL sworn Department employees, including those at substations.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 3 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Marcus Boyd

"This message originates from the Chatham County Attorney's Office.  The message and any file transmitted with it contain confidential information which may be subject to the attorney-client privilege, or otherwise protected against unauthorized use. Any disclosure, distribution, copying or use of the information by anyone other than the intended recipient, regardless of address or routing, is strictly prohibited.  All attachments are believed to be free of viruses, but any attachments should be checked for viruses before being opened.  If you have received this message in error, please advise the sender by immediate reply and delete the original message."

title: Massachusetts clemency application processing by the Governor

communications.subject: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request: Massachusetts clemency application processing by the Governor
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Massachusetts Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

All records from the date of the Governor's revised clemency guidelines issued 10/31/23 to the date that this request is filled related to the Governor's office's processing, approval and denial of clemency applications, including:
1. Every applicant whose petition for clemency was recommended to the Governor for approval by the Advisory Board of Pardons (ABP), including date of ABP recommendation.
2. Every applicant whose petition for clemency was recommended to the Governor for denial by the Advisory Board of Pardons, including date of ABP recommendation.
3. Whether the applicant requested a pardon or a commutation.
4.  For approval recommendations that the Governor accepted, how many days between the Advisory Board of Pardons recommendation and the Governor's recommendation.
5. For approval recommendations that the Governor did not accept, what steps, if any, did the Governor take on the recommendation.
6. For approval recommendations that are still pending at this time of this inquiry, how many days have they been pending since the Advisory Board of Pardons' recommendation to the Governor (or since what date have they been pending with the Governor).

I am seeking statistical information, not personal information, so it is fine with me if applicants' names are redacted.

I also request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as we believe this request is in the public interest, as suggested but not stipulated by the recommendations of the Massachusetts Supervisor of Public Records. The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, and is not made for commercial usage.

I expect the request to be filled in an accessible format, including for screen readers, which provide text-to-speech for persons unable to read print. Files that are not accessible to screen readers include, for example, .pdf image files as well as physical documents.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

David Weimer

communications.subject: Re: FOIA # 06276770 Extension
communications.communication:
December 30, 2024


Re: FOIA # 06276770 Extension

The Illinois State Police (ISP) acknowledges receipt of your attached Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request. A response to your request is due December 30, 2024. However, additional time is needed to respond to your request. In accordance with Section 3(e) of FOIA (5 ILCS 140/3(e)), ISP is extending the response due date for an additional five business days for the following reasons:

The requested records are stored in whole or in part at another location.

The request requires the collection of a substantial number of records.

The request is stated in categorical terms and requires an extensive search for the records requested.

X  The requested records have not yet been located and additional time is needed to complete the search.

X  The requested records require examination and evaluation to determine if the documents are exempt from disclosure and/or must be redacted.

X  The requested records cannot be provided within the prescribed time frame without causing an undue burden or interfering with the operation of ISP.

Consultation is needed with another public body in order to respond to the request.

ISP handles requests for video records separately. Depending on the records you requested, you may receive additional correspondence for either video or paper and audio records.

Sincerely,

Sarah Wheeler
Illinois State Police
Freedom of Information Officer
801 South 7th Street, Suite 1000-S
Springfield, Illinois  62703
ISP.FOIA.Officer@Illinois.gov

files.title: 06276770 Request (12-20-24)_PS
files.source: Illinois State Police, Illinois

communications.subject: Re: FOIA No. 06276770 Response
communications.communication:
January 6, 2025

Re: FOIA No. 06276770 Response

Thank you for writing the Illinois State Police (ISP) with your request for information pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA), 5 ILCS 140/1, et seq. ISP acknowledges receipt of your FOIA request received on December 20, 2024. A reasonable search for the requested records was conducted. ISP has included all responsive records that were located.

ISP is providing Investigative Report #22-41378100046. The requested records that ISP is providing are too voluminous to be sent via email; thus, they have been uploaded to the secure Microsoft Teams SharePoint Server and will be available for download at your convenience for the next 365 days here.

For the portion of your request concerning emails, ISP was unable to perform a search for emails based on the provided search terms. We invite you to submit a new request with more information that includes, but it not limited to, a list of keywords or phrases and date range.

ISP is granting your request in part and denying your request in part. The request was denied in part because some of the information in the records required redaction and/or were exempt from disclosure. The basis for the ISPs decision in this matter is as follows:

Section 7(1)(a) of FOIA: Subject to this requirement, the following shall be exempt from inspection and copying: (a) Information specifically prohibited from disclosure by federal or State law or rules and regulations implementing federal or State law. (5 ILCS 140/7(1)(a)).

Disclosure of some of the records you have requested is prohibited by federal or State law or rules and regulations implementing such laws.

20 Ill. Adm. Code 1240.80(d): LEADS data shall not be disseminated to any individual or organization that is not legally authorized to have access to the information. (20 Ill. Adm. Code 1240.80(d)).

Information gathered for the Law Enforcement Agency Data System (LEADS) cannot be provided to you because the dissemination of LEADS information to non-law enforcement persons and entities is prohibited.

Section 7(1)(b) of FOIA: Subject to this requirement, the following shall be exempt from inspection and copying: (b) Private information, unless disclosure is required by another provision of this Act, a State or federal law, or a court order. (5 ILCS 140/7(1)(b)).

Documents containing private information, as defined in 5 ILCS 140/2(c-5) have been redacted.

Section 7.5(bb) of FOIA: Statutory exemptions. To the extent provided for by the statutes referenced below, the following shall be exempt from inspection and copying: 
 (bb) Information which is or was prohibited from disclosure by the Juvenile Court Act of 1987. (5 ILCS 140/7.5(bb)).

Law enforcement records concerning specific minors under 18 years of age are exempt from public inspection and may not be disclosed to the public except by order of the court.

Section 7(1)(c) of FOIA: Personal information contained within public records, the disclosure of which would constitute a clearly unwarranted invasion of personal privacy, unless the disclosure is consented to in writing by the individual subjects of the information. Unwarranted invasion of personal privacy means the disclosure of information that is highly personal or objectionable to a reasonable person and in which the subjects right to privacy outweighs any legitimate public interest in obtaining the information. The disclosure of information that bears on the public duties of public employees and officials shall not be considered an invasion of personal privacy. (5 ILCS 140/7(1)(c)).

Documents containing personal information which would constitute a clearly unwarranted invasion of personal privacy have been redacted.

Section 7(1)(d)(vi) of FOIA: Subject to this requirement, the following shall be exempt from inspection and copying: 
 (d) Records in the possession of any public body created in the course of administrative enforcement proceedings, and any law enforcement or correctional agency for law enforcement purposes, but only to the extent that disclosure would: 
 (vi) endanger the life or physical safety of law enforcement personnel or any other person.

Releasing a portion of the requested records that outlines officer beat shifts or assignments would endanger the life or physical safety of law enforcement personnel.

You have the right to review by the Public Access Counselor (PAC) in the Office of the Attorney General (5 ILCS 140/9.5(a)). You may reach the PAC at:

500 S. 2nd Street
Springfield, Illinois 62701
(877) 299-3642
public.access@ilag.gov

You also have the right to judicial review under 5 ILCS 140/11.

Sincerely,

Sarah Wheeler
Illinois State Police
Freedom of Information Officer
801 South 7th Street, Suite 1000-S
Springfield, Illinois 62703
ISP.FOIA.Officer@Illinois.gov

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Natural Disaster Nutrition Assistance Expenditure
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

1.	Expenditures for any provision of nutritional assistance to individuals and households, including but not limited to bottled water, prepared food, or packaged food products for the years 2000-2024. Expenditures may include direct provision, contracted provision, or provision via another entity such as contribution to an interagency effort.
2.	Expenditures on the Disaster Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program, provisioned annually or by FEMA Disaster Number.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Johanna Rayl

Sincerely,

FNS FOIA Office

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request: Natural Disaster Nutrition Assistance Expenditure
communications.communication:
Dear FNS FOIA Office,

Thank you so much for the data provided. I have two questions to help me understand the records.

1. Could you elaborate on the column 3 title, "Number of LBS", on Sheet 2 of the record? What does LBS stand for and what does the column contain?
2. Does the total expense reflect both direct provision of food as well as expenditures on coupons/vouchers/cash for households to make their own food purchases? If so, is it possible to see a breakdown across these two categories, or would it require another FOIA request?

Thank you very much,
Johanna

communications.subject: RE: [External Email]RE: Freedom of Information Act Request: Natural Disaster Nutrition Assistance Expenditure
communications.communication:
Please see the response below regarding the 2 questions that you asked:

1.          LBS is the abbreviation for pounds and the column contains pounds of food distributed.
2.          The value provided is only for food distributed.  There is no cash issued for households to purchase their own foods.

communications.subject: RE: New Mexico Inspection of Public Records Act Request: Water Asset Management funds correspondence
communications.communication:
Dear Mr. Scroggins and Ms. Olsen,

Thanks for the update. Can you provide any additional info regarding the source of delays on this request, or the estimated delivery date? Please feel free to give me a call at 781-962-8816 if it'd be helpful to discuss the scope of the materials we're requesting.

communications.subject: RE: New Mexico Inspection of Public Records Act Request: Water Asset Management funds correspondence
communications.communication:
Dear Ms. Rock,

I am responding to your email yesterday requesting any additional info regarding the source of delays on this request. Please be assured that we make every effort to respond promptly to every request. However, we must also ensure that we are diligent and accurate in our reply. Thus, when obtained, all documents and emails must be reviewed. Additionally, we must rely on the state agency that controls the entire state email system to identify and provide the emails requested. As you can imagine, the process takes time.

As to an estimated response date, in our letter of August 1, 2023, we noted that we intend to respond by September 6, 2023.

Thank you for your patience and please feel free to contact me if you have further questions.

Respectfully,

[cid:image001.png@01D9C623.0D3F7D80]

files.title: image001
files.source: New Mexico Educational Retirement Board, New Mexico

communications.subject: RE: New Mexico Inspection of Public Records Act Request: Water Asset Management funds correspondence
communications.communication: OK, thank you! Look forward to your response. Please feel free to get in touch if it's helpful to chat about anything re: scope and number of documents responsive to the request.

communications.subject: RE: New Mexico Inspection of Public Records Act Request: Water Asset Management funds correspondence
communications.communication:
Hello Ms. Garcia,

Thank you for the update. Given that it's now been five months since we filed the initial request, are you able to provide an update as to whether you've identified the responsive documents, or what the source of the delay is?

Thank you,

Rebecca

communications.subject: ATTORNEY CLIENT PRIVILEGED - RE: [EXTERNAL] RE: New Mexico Inspection of Public Records Act Request: Water Asset Management funds correspondence
communications.communication:
Dear Ms. Rock and Ms. Burns,

Thank you for your inquiry and please accept our apologies for the delay.

As Mr. Scroggins noted in his August 3, 2023 email regarding our projected response, we always try to be prompt.  But as you might guess, the request references a large number of records.  As he said, we must thoroughly review all records to identify and obtain the responsive documents from both external and internal sources.  It is a complex and time-consuming process.

I am confident that we will have documents ready to provide on or before the December 6th, 2023, date noted in our recent communication.

Thank you for your continued patience!
Regards,
Renee



[cid:image002.png@01DA121F.C2136CB0]

files.title: image002
files.source: New Mexico Educational Retirement Board, New Mexico

communications.subject: RE: New Mexico Inspection of Public Records Act Request: Water Asset Management funds correspondence
communications.communication:
Hi,

Thanks so much for your help with this request! I really appreciate it.

Sincerely,
Julia Rock

communications.subject: Re: Request for Inspection of Records
communications.communication:
Dear Ms. Rock and Ms. Burns:

As discussed in our letter of December 6, 2023, we are providing the records we currently have available in response to your June 16, 2023, request.  They are located at the website below:

MuckRock - Julia Rock<https://nmgov-my.sharepoint.com/:f:/r/personal/renee_garcia_erb_nm_gov/Documents/MuckRock%20-%20Julia%20Rock?csf=1&web=1&e=4gwfSH>

As also discussed, we will require additional time to provide the remainder of the records.  We plan to provide additional documents on or before February 1, 2024.  Thank you again for your continued patience regarding this matter.
Regards,
Renee



[cid:image001.png@01DA29F0.5D899B00]

communications.subject: RE: New Mexico Inspection of Public Records Act Request: Water Asset Management funds correspondence
communications.communication:
Hello Renee,

Thank you for your continued partnership on this request. Please know that we are unable to access the SharePoint link you had provided. Our email address is not showing as associated with the link: 147140-15493170@requests.muckrock.com.

Please advise at your earliest convenience.

Thank You,

MuckRock Staff

communications.subject: RE: New Mexico Inspection of Public Records Act Request: Water Asset Management funds correspondence
communications.communication:
Hello Ms. Rock and Ms. Burns,

We apologize for the error you received while trying to access the records. We will be using another method for delivery. Attached are the instructions that you will need to connect to the ERB SFTP server.  I will send you the credentials in a secure email to follow this.

As also discussed, we will require additional time to provide the remainder of the records. We plan to provide additional documents on or before February 1, 2024. Thank you again for your continued patience regarding this matter.
Regards,
Renee



[cid:image001.png@01DA2C20.B2CBD790]

communications.subject: Illinois Freedom of Information Act. Request: HK - MA/FNB
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Illinois Freedom of Information Act., I hereby request the following records:

Records sufficient to show: Any correspondence, including emails, to and from Heather Keil with the words Touhy or 'Food Not Bombs',  from September 1, 2024 through November 1, 2024. Please include emails where Heather is cc'ed or bcc'ed.

Because this request is in the public interest for Illinois nonprofit Lucy Parsons Labs for the purpose of public education, please waive any fees in accordance with 5 ILCS § 140/6(c).“

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Alexandra Gelzin
